Posts.Content: When I was 30 I think I started to notice a weird sensation in my prostate area when I laughed hard or moved my legs in weird ways, that is about the closest experience I can share with you. When I was 33 I complained of pain in similar region, they deemed it prostatitis and I did a high dosage of Advil for 3 weeks, like 3 pills 3 times per day. It seemed to work, but we never did more tests. From what you describe I wouldn't wait, see a doctor, an annual physical with complete blood work can be done and they can include a PSA test, your doctor can also give you a DRE. You are young, are you healthy, drink water, exercise? Any family history? Either way, you've got this and I'm here to help. here is my thread http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...ge-41?p=177292
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer?

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear this, but you have found a great resource. If you want my copy of Dr. Walsh's book, send me your address and you can have my copy. With 8 out 12 positive with a GS6 (3+3) there stands a reasonable chance that at least one of them is GS7 (3+4, 4+3) but you'll never know that until the final pathology after removal which might never happen. Totally agree that watchful waiting as a long term strategy is tough when it more than 2 positive biopsy but as to say whether waiting 6 months will be a critical period of time, is not clear. Is the idea that when you turn 65 you will have health insurance?

Posts.Title: Wait til next year?

Posts.Content: Good luck my friend. I'm going under the robotic knife tomorrow morning at 730AM, the cancer has just 23 more hours to enjoy its visit in my body and then it is gone for good. God can reshape this piece of clay any which way he sees fit, I'm ready for it, BRING IT ON!

Posts.Title: Surgery Monday

Posts.Content: 1. Revised Gleason Score. 2. Status of the margins (capsular lining).
Posts.Title: Questions for the Doctor

Posts.Content: great news all around. congratulations and happy living.
Posts.Title: DaVinci 6/25/2013

Posts.Content: When I did the education process I definitely liked the NCCN information and didn't get Walsh's book until the last phase of the education process. I think the best way to determine if you have all the information you need to make a decision is to keep looking for more and when you get to a point that nothing is new, then you know you've got enough to decide.
Posts.Title: NCCN Guidelines for Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: I really (really) appreciate the information above and the way Chuck described the downsides of radiation (for my situation) is precisely what I was alluding to in terms of being in a "worse position". What I am doing in April is meeting with several urologists to review their statistics and bedside manner in preparation for surgery. I also am trying to meet with the pathologist and the MRI radiologist to get their input on how the imagergy lines up with the biopsy and learn more about the 3rd core that was sample. There were 2 "nodules on the prostate" that were clearly visible in the MRI so it wasn't surprising those came back at 5%, but it is the 3rd core that is a distance aways from the other 2 that came back at <5% and that is the piece of data that has me convinced that the cancer is spreading. I have witnessed enough things in life that I am a full believer that "things happen for a reason" so having this PF condition and finding PCa is indeed one of those cases, not that the decision is easy, but God gives us these challenges to make us better people. I always watch this video clip to keep my spirits up Link removed per new user policy. Please review policy at the top of this forum. and remind myself that everything in life is temporary and life is always changing.

Posts.Title: diagnosed with prostate cancer at age 41

Posts.Content: I will explore focal treatment, it sounds like a fancy name for radiation, I guess I need to give it more viability as an option, thank you. | The DRE comes back fine, no issues. | I am starting yoga soon and will be exploring meditation as well. I think that if I can change the state of my overall being that AS might become more of an option. | Thanks again.

I think that if I can change the state of my overall being that AS might become more of an option. | Thanks again.
Posts.Title: diagnosed with prostate cancer at age 41

Posts.Content: January 7th I got the results from the biopsy 3 out of 12 cores with 5% or less with a GS of 6 and a PSA of 1.9 | Nearly 3 years ago I started to have a pelvic cramp (proctalgia fugax (PF)) occur every 2 months at night and the pain is moderate to severe and lasts for 30 minutes, so this past fall I did tests (colonoscopy, pelvic MRI) which resulted in seeing nodules on the prostate so I did the test above which is why I found out about the cancer. All the doctors feel the PF is not due to the PC and the PF will go away in a couple more years. So the question becomes... how to treat the PC given that if it wasn't for the PF I wouldn't know I had PC. Welcome to my world! All doctors (urologists, radiation oncologists, medical oncologists) do not support any form of radiation as my age is such that eventually I'll be in a worse position after radiation and then things will just go downhill. So that is off the table. Does everyone agree? All urologists suggests that because of my age, being very healthy, sexual function is great, the prostate is small (24.9mg), the pelvic MRI showed there is plenty of space to operate, that the best decision is surgery. (highly curable) One medical oncologists suggests to do deferment management (DM)such that in 5 years I would just move toward surgery so that the scenario described above still exists. Another thinks that the statistical construct of the situation is such that I should move on with my life, forget this even happened, and not worry about a thing until something doesn't feel right or I get another test in 5 years. So I explore the concept of DM and also AS and think about a program of doing a PSA every 3 months and biopsy every 6 months. Most feel this is too frequent, but there is no rule on frequency. I am convinced the biopsy is a great test but also very random in nature. In my case, the MRI clearly shows 2 small areas that are in seperate regions so the biopsy is not so random. I have a hard time living each day knowing I have cancer. I have friends who have died because they waited for treatment, I know people who have other cancers and they are in chemotherapy and hoping to live. But my closest family wants me to hold on to the chance of having a family (I am 41 and single and no kids) the normal way. I am not rushing into anything, running a half marathon in May, another biopsy in June (it will be 6 months) and then a full marathon in July. If the biopsy comes back with higher scores, I'm thinking surgery in August. Ok, so that is my deal. What makes sense of what I described, what doesn't? I appreciate all input. Thank you.

All doctors (urologists, radiation oncologists, medical oncologists) do not support any form of radiation as my age is such that eventually I'll be in a worse position after radiation and then things will just go downhill. So that is off the table. Does everyone agree? All urologists suggests that because of my age, being very healthy, sexual function is great, the prostate is small (24.9mg), the pelvic MRI showed there is plenty of space to operate, that the best decision is surgery. (highly curable) One medical oncologists suggests to do deferment management (DM)such that in 5 years I would just move toward surgery so that the scenario described above still exists. Another thinks that the statistical construct of the situation is such that I should move on with my life, forget this even happened, and not worry about a thing until something doesn't feel right or I get another test in 5 years. So I explore the concept of DM and also AS and think about a program of doing a PSA every 3 months and biopsy every 6 months. Most feel this is too frequent, but there is no rule on frequency. I am convinced the biopsy is a great test but also very random in nature. In my case, the MRI clearly shows 2 small areas that are in seperate regions so the biopsy is not so random. I have a hard time living each day knowing I have cancer. I have friends who have died because they waited for treatment, I know people who have other cancers and they are in chemotherapy and hoping to live. But my closest family wants me to hold on to the chance of having a family (I am 41 and single and no kids) the normal way. I am not rushing into anything, running a half marathon in May, another biopsy in June (it will be 6 months) and then a full marathon in July. If the biopsy comes back with higher scores, I'm thinking surgery in August. Ok, so that is my deal. What makes sense of what I described, what doesn't? I appreciate all input. Thank you.
Posts.Title: diagnosed with prostate cancer at age 41

Posts.Content: I had PSA of 1.9 for 2 years and it wasn't rising but a MRI showed a couple nodules on the prostate. The biopsy came back with 3 out 12 positive with GS6 (3+3) and the PSA prior to surgery was 3.6 and the pathology after surgery upgraded it to GS7 (3+4). I was 41 when this happened and today I'm 42 and it has been 12 weeks since surgery. I am very glad I took action. I would suggest to consider "your time" is the time it takes to become educated and make the right decision, after the biopsy. It might take 1 hour or 6 months, but make sure you understand the decision you are making before signing up for treatment.
Posts.Title: Should I do a Prostate Biopsy ? are my chances for recovery better if diagnosed early

Posts.Content: I had PSA of 1.9 for 2 years and it wasn't rising but a MRI showed a couple nodules on the prostate. The biopsy came back with 3 out 12 positive with GS6 (3+3) and the PSA prior to surgery was 3.6 and the pathology after surgery upgraded it to GS7 (3+4). Posts.Title: T-Minus 36 Hours until da Vinci...

Posts.Content: I am 42 (just turned in May) and just went thru this experience and you can read about it at this thread http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...ncer-at-age-41 I know all too well about the age range and how clueless our friends are about men's health, trust me, I'll help you in any way I can. Dial-in your health care plan and find out if you have a network that limits your options (for me I had a New England Plan so I couldn't go outside unless I waited until 2014 to switch plans). Try to get a consultation at a hospital from a team of doctors (urologist, oncologist, radiation oncologist) and get "their" collective input. I can not imagine anyone will suggest radiation, for 38 you are way too young to take an approach that could lead its own issues. Surgery will likely be the option you choose, but you need to advocate for your own health, don't rely on anyone to make that decision. You are lucky to have kids already, but I didn't and I went with surgery, went to the sperm-bank and 18 days later the impotence is a non-issue, my doctor saved both nerves and I'm almost ready for the major leagues! Start reading, think good thoughts, do not panic.
Posts.Title: 38 years old, high PSA

Posts.Content: Hi. I am turning 42 next week and live in Rhode Island and was diagnosed in January and heading towards surgery in late June. I can share with you anything and everything I've learned. I have not heard of those doctors but they probably work at south county or within the same group as Renzulli. Mega is a great oncologist at Miriam. I also liked the group at MGH in Boston. | What I learned thru all of it (besides what feels like everything) is that I can't live with cancer in my body, I have to get it out. Once i came to that realization, the process of figuring out what to do because very simple. I am T1C, PSA 1.9, GS6 (3+3) and 3 out of 12 cores positive. I could make a HUGE case for going with active surveillance, but it just isn't a viable for option for how my brain is wired. Feel free to get in touch with me. Thanks
Posts.Title: treatment in rhode island

Posts.Content: good luck and think positive and great things will happen.
